elementText.text: NYC Yoga Studios Archive - A CUNY Project Courtney Stapleford Contribution Brooklyn Yoga Teacher Interview

element.name: Duration
element.description: Length of time involved (seconds, minutes, hours, days, class periods, etc.)

element.name: Transcription
element.description: Any written text transcribed from a sound

elementText.text:
Courtney 0:00

My quick origin story, I am originally from Long Island. I've lived in the city for the last several years, many, many years. I went to college in the city and I kind of stayed here since. I work for a nonprofit. I work in the field of mental health, and I also teach a couple yoga classes. Oh, fun fact, I have three dogs who you hear in the background wrestling. It was kind of like a Brady Bunch situation when my partner and I moved in together. So I brought two dogs to the relationship and he brought one so I have a 13 year old Pitbull named Vita. We have a nine year old Pitbull named Jack's and a six year old Australian shepherd named Zag. So I'm almost like a little embarrassed to say but my foray into yoga was as a high school student. As a junior I was invited. This is like so embarrassing. I was invited to the prom as junior with my senior boyfriend at the time. And all of the girls who were trying to like lose weight. We're going to take Bikram yoga classes. So I went to Bikram a couple times and I actually like maybe with the like, kind of unhealthy way that I was like trying to lose weight at the classes. I was like, Oh, this is really cool. Like, I grew up playing sports. I played soccer for most of my life. We played field hockey in high school a little bit. And I really liked that yoga was like athletic, but also like, quiet. I have a very noisy brain. So I connected very strongly with that anyway, so I continued to practice, kind of on and off. Throughout college, I didn't really have like a home base per se, but like, you know, I joined the student center when I was in college, and I would always have yoga classes, I went to Fordham University for College in the Bronx. And like, as every kind of broke college kid was doing at that time was also going to Yoga to the People controversy. But anyway, I graduated in 2014, and moved home briefly to Long Island. And there was a great little studio there called Yogananda, which unfortunately does not exist anymore. But it was right down the street from my parents house. And I started going there because I just like, needed something to do. And I really loved the community, I loved the classes, I loved the I loved all of it, I was very, I mean, I jumped in with both feet. So that was in 2014, when I kind of like, began more of what I would say like a regular practice. Moved back to the city in like 2015-2016 and kind of bounced around between different studios in Brooklyn, like Goodyoga at the time.


Courtney 3:03

And in like 2017-2018 is when I found Kula, actually kind of going back. The original way that I found out about Kula was my very first job out of college, I worked for a showroom briefly, that did like wholesale. Buying for, like different accounts. I know, it was like sales, for one of the brands that they manage was Manduka, like the yoga mats. And when I was working there, it was when they were coming out with our first line of clothing. So it's very exciting. But anyway, so we would go to studios that stocked Manduka products and like, meet the teachers and take the classes there and like, buy like they would buy the products. And anyway, so that was how I like kind of became more involved in like the yoga scene in New York City. Like I was going into studios like House of Jai, which also doesn't exist anymore, very sad and Yoga Maya, which also just recently reopened.


Courtney 4:04

Anyway, so when I started practicing at Kula was in like 2017-2018. And I completely like fell in love with the studio with all of the teachers with the style of yoga that they teach there. And that became kind of like my home base. And in 2020, is when I did my yoga teacher training there. So we started the teacher training in January pre shutdown. And the first nine days of the training was so magical because it was like an intensive so we were at the studio all day, for like nine days in a row. And then it was like, a like every other weekend type thing for a couple of months. But then obviously like in March, everything shut down. So we wrapped up the training on Zoom. And here we are today. It was just so I mean like, I don't know, sometimes I still don't have the language, I feel like to fully like capture what it was, like live through that experience of just like COVID. But, um, yeah, I mean, these were people that I had I had spent so much time with. So I really looked forward to having those meetings on Zoom and still like meeting as a teacher training group, because it was so like, that experience of being a teacher training with other individuals is so like, so many things, and so intense. And then to like, have to kind of immediately transition to this fully not spending time with each other in person type situation, very, like traumatic in a way. So suffice to say, I really looked forward to having classes and meetings on Zoom, because I was missing that community.


Courtney 5:54

I think everybody has taken classes online with Yoga with Adriene on YouTube. So I definitely had taken some classes online, but it was not really my thing. Like I really enjoy going to the studio, I think that they were doing the best that they can with the information that they had at the time. And there were some, maybe modules that I felt more like, Oh, this is really like, not making me feel like I'm missing out on anything. And then like some other ones, where I might like have the teacher training on but also like be baking, you know?


Courtney 6:27

I did not teach classes. So when we finished the teacher training, um, I felt very, like, a little bit disillusioned because I had no frame of reference. Like to be a yoga teacher under like, normal circumstances. You come out of teacher training, you're feeling so many things. Like you're so excited, and like, they have all this information that. And like, I should say that, like, when I started the teacher training, I wasn't necessarily like, Oh, I'm going to be a yoga teacher, I just really loved Kula and practicing there and was like, I want to, like, see what this about. And kind of through that process was like, Okay, this is something that I also want people, um, but had not obviously taught in a studio, or to that point. So you know, being like a brand new baby yoga teacher, and like, dealing with the vicarious trauma of COVID, trying to, like, teach my friends and family on Zoom, and, like, feel good about what I was doing did was not something that felt good for me. I just felt like really unnatural. Like, I was playing a part, you know, um, I think and like, maybe fortunately, or unfortunately, like, I think the teachers that were successful online, were teachers that already had a following of students from studios. Which obviously was not anything that I had. So then, you know, it's like really kind of demoralizing, a little bit like for your ego. Which, like, it's not really about the ego. But I don't know, to feel like you want to do this thing so badly, and then have so many barriers in the way of like, being able to deliver that thing. I felt like, Okay, I don't know, like, what I'm actually doing and, or if I'm even going to actually pursue this ultimately. So I did not teach really at all in the year of 2020 When I finished my teacher training, like maybe every once in a while for like a friend, very small scale. But I took classes outdoors when people were offering like, socially distanced classes, I'm pretty sure they were in 2020. And I don't know it was definitely like a mix of feelings like wanting to be in that environment with other students so badly and like practicing with other bodies, but also being like so sketched out about COVID.


Courtney 8:59

Um, it was definitely unprecedented times. It did not feel like a good time to me, I felt stressed and like I was trying too hard. If that makes sense. Um, which of course like the feedback I got was always like, Oh my gosh, that was so great. But I'm such a critic of myself. And like in the early days, I would be like, that was terrible. Um, so didn't feel great and I am not like a techy person by any means. There is no cute layout in my apartment to get like a good angle with like some plants and like good lighting like that does not exist in my apartment. So it never really took off for me 2020 COVID Teacher Training like land for me in a way that I felt like I was delivering something that felt like I would want to share it with others at that time. Um, did a lot of like reflection and like, you know, reconnecting to my practice myself. And then in 2021, when things started to like, open up a little bit more, I was like, Okay, we're doing this, like I didn't, I want to do this, I have to kind of infer myself if I want, like, you know, like, there is a seat for me at this table somewhere, and I am going to go find it. So, um, I started teaching at a few. Well, so originally started teaching at Stacked Yoga, she used to have a spot on Tompkins and then was like renting space or, like, teaching classes out of a spot on Nostrand. So I had a little audition and I started teaching a couple classes. I actually did teach a class outdoors for them a few times, there were a couple classes in Herbert Von King. And they were also doing classes during the Sunday street closure on Tompkins during Open Streets, and that was super fun.


Courtney 11:03

Like, I don't know, I, I have like, I still deal with this a lot. Like as a teacher, like I had a lot of impostor syndrome. When I first started, I really enjoyed it. So I was like, you know, you get a little taste, and you're like, Okay, I want to I want more. Um, so from there, I started teaching at some other studios in Brooklyn. And then in 2022, is when I started teaching at Kula, in the spring of 2022, I got my feet wet a little bit. And then I went back to the place that I did my training. And I was like, Okay, let's do this.


Courtney 11:42

In like 2021, when I was like, regularly starting to teach classes at a studio in Brooklyn, the classes were both in person, and livestream all of the classes all of the time. I was not, not into it, but I found it. And this is something that I have, like worked on in like, in my teaching, that I like to deliver to folks. But I found it really difficult at first to like, be present with students in classroom and also students online. And I could not find a way to make that feel like I was giving both of them enough of myself to like, make it a great experience for both people. Because for a while, like, yes, the studios were slowly reopening, but it was still like kind of sketchy to be going to classes and I wore a mask for a while when I was teaching at first. I would take classes wearing I mean, we had to for a while. But like even beyond like when it was still kind of more optional. I was wearing a mask. Anyway, so I thought it was a great and like, interestingly enough, like when I was first starting out, like right after my teacher training, when I was trying to do Zoom, I would, I was like kind of like screw this, like I don't like doing this. But then getting into a studio and teaching classes in studio. It's like, oh, this is a wonderful. And like, I don't know why this person doesn't want to come in, like why dont they come take class? Like, it's amazing that you can find ways to take a live yoga class at your house. And a lot of the classes that I was teaching at that point, were both so it was something that I just sort of got used to. And now I am teaching a mix, I would say of classes that are live streamed and in person. And then just in person, I don't teach truly online. Like I know a lot of people will do like a personal like zoom class or whatever. I think that's amazing. I just didn't really connect to that.


Courtney 13:53

I still take classes online sometimes. Like sometimes it's just really hard to get to the studio and I'll throw on a class 45 minutes in my backyard if it's nice out or in my bedroom and I'll, I'll do my thing. And, um, yeah, I don't know, I mean, the whole mask thing. Um, I still wear a mask on the train. And sometimes I think like people are ready to like, just pretend this whole thing never happened. But like, on a fundamental level, like we're different. Um, but yeah, yeah, I remember having like, thoughts about masks in class, like, I mean, throughout in one class, like I could, like run the gamut of like, so many things that I felt about my mask like, Oh, this is so annoying. Like, Oh, I'm so grateful that I can be in this class, but I have to wear this mask. I can't breathe because of the mask like, um, I mean, I don't really know what else to say. Like it's just pretty unbelievable that we like we're going to yoga classes in the middle of a pandemic and wearing face masks, right? Like, you know, just like, it was weird. It was weird times.


Courtney 15:08

I mean, I am biased, but I think Kula has one of the best online libraries of classes in the biz. They have all sorts of different length classes, all from sorts of different style classes. It's, I mean, like, it's just such a great, great catalog. of yoga classes. Um, there's another one that I really like called the movement method. I hope I'm, I hope I'm saying definitely is like movement method, movement method co Yes. Two really wonderful teachers who are kind of like in the Kula-sphere that do a lot of like, yoga with like, functional movement kind of type of classes that I really, really liked. Um, I think there's some really great things available online. And like, for the movement method thing, like, in particular, like, they, like one of the people lives in Canada. So like, I'm taking a class that was filmed by the teacher in Canada, we've never met, but like, it's such a cool like connection.


Courtney 16:16

More likely than not, people are not wearing masks. Every once in a while, I'll have like a one off student that will have a mask on and I completely see and respect their decision. I'm like, kind of to your point like I am. So I'm a little surprised, like more people aren't, especially now like, we have this crazy, like air quality stuff again. I mean, it's just like, can you catch a break? But no, I would say for the most part, people are not wearing masks.


Courtney 16:50

Um, I'm teaching for regular classes right now, I often saw that a couple studios in Brooklyn, I have a full time nine to five job for a non-profit I think I mentioned earlier. And I feel, I mean, like, broadly speaking, I feel like I wish I could teach more. But I'm just not in a position right now that I can step away from my full time job, which is my goal. But yeah, I'm having a blast. I love teaching, I feel so lucky to be able to like be the agent for which someone can have an amazing experience because like, I've had so many amazing experiences. Taking class with teachers that I love and like to be able to, like have that privilege of providing that to someone is so cool and like special. So Prospect Park, I have not actually taught the class yet. But Brooklyn Flow, formerly Bend and bloom. There are a few teachers involved in that studio that are also involved with Kula. And they do this summer series, I think, like, pretty pretty much every summer that they'll have Brooklyn Flow teachers interspersed with other teachers. Actually remember something else that I'll add when I finished this, um, but like, one week, Brooklyn Flow another week, another teacher. And so they reached out to Nikki, who is the studio director at Kula, she's amazing. And she reached out to me and was like, would you want to do this? And I was like, absolutely. I think that's so cool. So I'm super pumped. It's on August on August 17. I believe at 7pm. And I would love for you to come. That would be the biggest class that I've ever taught. And I feel extremely honored to have been asked, I really do look up to a lot of these teachers. What's really cool to be like, kind of included in that group. I think it's very, very cool.


Courtney 19:08

And then the other thing I was going to add that I should have mentioned is that last summer so summer 22. I did my 300 hour at the Shala which is a lovely, lovely studio in Fort Greene. And they do a park series also in Fort Greene Park. And they are out there every Saturday. It is so much fun. And so I taught a bunch of those classes last summer, or not, maybe not a bunch, but a decent amount. It was super, super fun. It's a lot of the same people that show up so it's really cool. And like I think I had done one in the fall of 20 Yes, because the training started in the fall of 2021. So I taught one of the park classes in the fall and then taught another one in May and it was like all the same people so it was really cool like seeing all of these people after like the winter and spring and we're all out like doing yoga again in Fort Greene park like amazing.


Courtney 20:00

Yeah, I think I always have hope you know, you have to that's like, that's the thing that you have to believe that like, there is going to be a better thing beyond the great thing that we have right now. Um, I think it's, I think it's formed over time through trust. And I'm, what is the word I'm looking for? Commitment and like mutual investment by both parties. Um, and I think when you find a place you love, like you love that place, and you want to keep going. And I think that yes, these communities definitely took a hit during COVID. Like, how could they not have, but it was almost like, and in no way am I saying like, we needed the pandemic to happen, but like, we become so like, Americans are so individualistic, like, me, me, me, me, me. And it's almost like we needed this kind of, like, Come to Jesus like level like moment to be like, like, let's be grateful for our communities and like, show up for each other.


Courtney 21:17

Because like, we don't know, like, what the future holds and we should, like, make the most out of every opportunity that we have to like, live to the fullest. It is so cheesy, but like it is, you know, but words of advice. I would say like keep going, you know, there is no way to do this practice wrong. I think that's why it's so amazing and why despite all of this like hardship, the yoga community has continued to like be here because like it's so special and you can use it when you need it to get through tough shit.

element.name: Time Summary
element.description: A summary of an interview given for different time stamps throughout the interview

elementText.text:
Summary

  • Origin story of yoga. 0:00
    • She is originally from Long Island and has lived in the city for the last several years. She works for a mental health nonprofit.
    • She has three dogs, including a 13 year old pitbull.
  • How she got involved in yoga. 2:17
    • In 2014, she started going to a yoga studio called Yogananda, which does not exist anymore, but it was right down the street from her parents house.
    • In 2017 and 2018, she found Kula and fell in love with the studio with all of the teachers.
  • Wrapping up teacher training on zoom. 4:51
    • We wrapped up the teacher training on zoom and here we are today.
    • She shares what it was like to be in teacher training with other individuals in person and online.
  • Teaching yoga in a studio. 7:07
    • Being a brand new baby yoga teacher and dealing with the vicarious trauma of COVID-19 was not something that felt good for her.
    • In the year of 2020, she did not teach much at all, but took classes outdoors when people were offering socially distanced classes.
  • Teaching at a few different studios. 9:58
    • When things started to open up a little bit more in 2021, she started teaching at a few different studios in Brooklyn.
    • She had a lot of impostor syndrome when she first started teaching, but she has worked on it in her teaching.
  • Yoga in person vs. online classes. 13:07
    • Yoga classes during the pandemic were both live-streamed and in-person, and a lot of the classes that she was teaching at that time were both.
    • Yoga in the middle of a pandemic.
  • Movement Method Yoga. 15:08
    • Cooler has one of the best online libraries of classes in the biz. There are also great classes available online, such as the movement method.
  • Teaching at Prospect Park. 17:20
    • She feels lucky to be able to be the agent for which someone can have an amazing experience taking a class with teachers she loves.
    • Last summer, she did her 300 hour at the Shala
  • Yoga in Fort Greene Park. 19:35
    • Yoga in Fort Greene Park is a lot of the same people that show up, and it was really cool to see all of the people after the winter and spring.
    • Yoga is special and you can use it when you need it to get through tough shit.

Summer Yoga in Battery Park, New York City
We create a special mission this summer to o!er everyday yoga in Battery Park, New York City. We value time and we believe that it is something we cant buy or replace. We believe that self-care is a foundation for human peace, clear and adequate decisions, and well-being.This summer we have regular yoga classes in Battery Park, New York City, Special Yoga Classes. Spots will be limited to 18 students to stay within Parks regulations. In order to accommodate teacher salaries, we will have to limit member attendance to one complimentary Special Battery Park Yoga Summer Series class each week. We will begin to teach on April, 9. 2022 If you have any questions, contact us at info@beunewyork.com or call us 917-791-2666

itemType.name: Text & Written Interview Responses
itemType.description: A resource consisting primarily of words for reading. Examples include interview responses, books, letters, dissertations, poems, newspapers, articles, archives of mailing lists. Note that facsimiles or images of texts are still of the genre Text.

element.name: Text
element.description: Any textual data included in the document

elementText.text: My friend Dasha asked me to go-teach the first yoga class at this immersive Van Gogh exhibit in Chelsea. It was the first public indoor class I taught since March 2020 when the yoga studios in NYC closed temporarily at first and then permanently as a result of the covid-19 pandemic. We were required to wear masks, students socially-distanced and we had to use hand sanitizer before and after practice. This was an incredible experience for me. Not only was I able to teach in-person again (which I hadnt done in a public space for more than a year at the time), but I also got to lead class in such a dynamic and unique space: bursts of saffron and cerulean splattered and swerved on the walls, the moody lighting gave a psychedelic vibe and the I could feel how excited the students were to just be in a cool place together safely (as safely as they could be) again. It was fantastic; I had missed teaching public classes. At the time, I had a robust virtual yoga following and many private yoga clients but theres something special about teaching public classes - they feel dynamic and new and engaging in a wholly new way, and I was lucky enough to teach a public class in such a cool space. -Janel Feliz Martir.

elementText.text:
Nick 0:00

My name is Nick. I am the owner and operator of Yoga Agora in Astoria, Queens, and St. Mark's Yoga on St. Mark's place in the East Village. I opened Yoga Agora in 2010, and St. Mark's yoga is still relatively new. We opened that one in July 2021, after the COVID shutdowns had been lifted.


Nick 0:29

And I have a personal love for the practice of yoga, I think it's, for me the perfect recipe of keeping physical, mental and social health in the most pristine condition. It can be physically moving the body, stretching muscles and strengthening muscles and getting the joints loosened up and getting the blood flow churning, I think are among the most available low hanging fruits we have for better body functioning, physical functioning in the world. And then, you know, going through those physical exercises with a sense of mindfulness awareness, feeling your legs step forward into a lunge and feeling your lower spine as you're twisting helps you know that that mind to body connection, I think it's a very powerful way of reducing stress, and increasing euphoria, mentally. So that is an important ingredient. And then, and then the social health aspect. I think there is a lot of talk of physical health and mental health, but maybe we forget that social health is as important of a pillar in that equation. And, you know, coming together in a community with other humans who are also sharing in those exercises and sharing, in that pinpointed focus moving in unison with other humans. And then, you know, having a little bit of small talk, and hello, how you doing little negotiation, when you go to a cubby shelf, and you try to put your stuff in at the same time you say, oops, sorry about that. Oh, no, you know, those little micro-interactions, I think, are hugely important for our just overall well being and our overall happiness in the world. And so, yeah, yoga felt like the perfect recipe of physical, mental and social health benefits. And so I fell in love with it. And then that love for the practice inspired me and motivated me to open a studio space where I could, you know, really put my energy full throttle into expanding its access.


Nick 2:58

Yeah, Astoria was a, Astoria is a really, really great neighborhood. In 2010, it felt like Astoria was the kind of neighborhood where new city residents, especially if they were young, are fresh out of college, and especially if they were a freelancer or an artist, or, you know, if they were young and living on a budget. Astoria was a perfect neighborhood. And especially for artists and creatives and maybe even more, especially for those in the theater community because it's a very easy commute into the theater districtm Midtown Manhattan. It's geographic, the proximity of Astoria to Manhattan is very convenient. And it was quite affordable. And there are several, you know, two bedroom, three bedroom apartments that a couple, you know, college grads could all share. So, yeah, there were a lot of young people and a story of we're living on a budget and at the time in 2010, you know, New York City. I mean, I guess New York City is always kind of an expensive place.


Nick 4:18

But a lot of yoga studios, were, you know, yoga was getting was hugely was so popular throughout the 2000s. Even, you know, by the mid-90's, Madonna and Sting, you know, celebrities were talking about yoga and yoga became very, I guess, fashionable. And so some yoga communities, you know, for their own understandable reasons, used that trendiness to make it more financially successful or whatever the word might be for it, but it was expensive. And you know, a lot of young people, especially, maybe, you know, theater type dancers, and so on yoga can be very helpful for their creative pursuits. So they were interested in practicing yoga, but maybe couldn't afford other places. So, Astoria, which was a neighborhood where a lot of those types were living, seemed like a perfect spot to open a yoga studio, that was especially affordable. And since the rent was affordable, and since I and other of my colleagues were working together, were as passionate about the pursuit as we were, we were able to create a yoga space that could operate on $5 classes. It could operate soundly, the rent could get paid, the teachers could get well paid, ConEd could get paid, everything could work out financially. The space was large enough that as long as it filled up, we could operate on $5 classes. So, so that's what we did. And in 2010, the neighborhood was, it was, it was just perfect, you know, you just open it up. And people came pretty quickly, you know, it took about two years to, you know, like any business, any small business, you're going to need up, there's a lot of upfront costs. I had saved a decent amount of money doing like barbacking, and bike messaging, you know, I spent years doing that kind of stuff in the early 2000s. So I'd save some money, use that money to open the yoga space. And within two years, the money that was spent on it, I was able to recoup.


Nick 4:37

And in that time, Astoria has grown quite a bit. And a lot of, a lot of investments have been made, maybe more so in Long Island City, which is just south of Astoria but still in Astoria itself. Some old you know, business institutions have closed down and new condos have been built in their place. New people have moved in. Some people call that gentrification. Okay, you know, there's a lot of different words for it. And maybe some of those words have a negative connotation or a positive connotation, depending on who you ask. But certainly Astoria is very special in that there are a lot of old time local residents. And so there are, I think, in any given class, you can find a good handful of students there who will talk about I remember coming here in 2010, and 2011. And they're still coming today. Because Astoria feels like the kind of place. It's hard to say why exactly my theory is, because Astoria is kind of, it's not like isolated, but it's the kind of place where like, for instance, the yellow line, it ends at Ditmars. And it's not necessarily the kind of place you're passing through on your way somewhere else. Maybe if you're going to the US Open and Flushing sure, then maybe you just pass through Astoria. Otherwise, if you're coming across the 59th Street Bridge, in some way, you're coming specifically to land in Astoria, and because of that, it feels like like an insular neighborhood. Not so transient people who come are meaning to come. And as a result of, I think the the feeling is very grounded and rooted. So, though new people have moved in, certainly, there's still a core group of the Western Queens you know, community.


Nick 9:10

Yeah, I guess the process of keeping the community together during those shutdown months really is a testament of the Astoria community itself and the Yoga Agora instructors themselves, Because a lot of sacrifice was made with our time and our resources and our finances to keep it together. And I'm very lucky to have that community around me taking - it takes a village - we hear that all the time. But wow, I mean, what a what an amazing lesson COVID was to really understanding that concept, it takes a village.


Nick 9:55

So during the shutdown months, when we were doing we did Zoom call classes at first. Which yeah, the, the original iteration was, hey, go home for two weeks. Okay, no problem. So everyone for next two weeks, we're gonna do Zoom. And yeah, we'll see in two weeks, and then we know what happened after that. But yeah, Zoom classes to start, and people got on. And, you know, there was a lot of discipline and commitment to keeping up the practice, even in the living room on Zoom. But certainly by the time you start getting into the warmer months, and even by late April and early May, it's spring time, you could see the Zoom classes, the Zoom room was thinning out. People are going outside, and by then it was kind of, we understood that outdoor transmission was not a real risk. So people are taking advantage of outdoor activities. You know, there was the, you know, it was a summer of George Floyd and activism became, you know, even those who never participated in marches or anything before said, you know, this would be a good time in history to get involved a little bit more with community activism.


Nick 11:13

So outdoor, outdoor activity was proving to be safe, and maybe even much needed, because it allowed you to see others. So, as the Zoom Room is thinning out, and as people are enjoying the outdoors, we had an opportunity to take advantage of a new house that you know, the open streets are, yeah, so Open Streets is pretty popular now. But in the summer of 2020, it was still kind of like an obscure concept. And there's an amazing community activist here in a story named Evie on cyclists. And Evie actually lives just down the street from Yoga Agora, and I see her all the time. And she's awesome. You know, she's, she's a local mom, school board, community board. And she's just like all about town, just like hustling and doing awesome stuff, and is always in a good mood. She's awesome. And she applied for this obscure Open Streets permit on 31st Avenue. And she made the mention to me say, "Hey, listen, I'm thinking about you know, or I'm working on getting 31st Avenue made it into an Open Street," "What's an open street?" "Oh, just means you can't have traffic and you can use this pedestrian thorough way. So we can do activities there. You want to do your yoga classes?" And my answer, "Oh, sure. Why not? Sounds great." Okay, but I didn't really know much about it. And she helped quarterback, outdoor yoga classes. And all we had to do is announce it to our people through Instagram or email list. And then on July 1, we announced that we're gonna have an outdoor yoga class on 31st Avenue. 31st Avenue, open street. Come on by, it's donation based, you know, it's very public, anyone can come. And and then that, you know, planted the seed for our outdoor classes. And yeah, that's, that's what the shutdown once kind of felt like. Yeah, the - so yes, now we have like a full on regular schedule of outdoor classes, and there definitely has been an evolution in it. So while we started on the 31st Avenue, Open Street, what back when, again, no one really knew what an Open Street is. Open streets have become very, very popular. And that's a little bit. I don't know, it's not like harder to get a spot. But there's more people with stands and shops, it's not really so conducive for outdoor yoga these days. So as Open Streets became more popular, and also as the first winter set in. So I'm kind of all over the place.


Nick 14:03

But yeah, that the summer of 2020 we had open streets all the way through into November, and then the winter setting and the open street permit had expired. And so there was no more 31st Avenue open street. So what we did was we pivoted the yoga classes to another to another park nearby called Athens Square, which has like a flat surface courtyard. And we started and also has like this big gorgeous holiday tree. So it was like just so scenic and perfect and very like we even though it was like mid December, it felt warm. It's just like spiritually just felt warm. And we did outdoor classes there in Athens Square. And all through the winter. I mean, it was wild, you know, I mean, it was like, we had 6pm classes. It's already pitch black Dark. There was like, you know a couple there was like two, you know, elderly ladies who came every class. Other random people would like fall in one spot. So there's three people, four people, whatever. We're doing the classes outdoors, which is also kind of surprising. You know, it's like maybe the testament to yoga to Ujayi breathing through your nose, you do warm up you.... It's pretty amazing. And so we did the classes there throughout the winter. As that winter subsided, we got back into now the Spring of 2021 Open Streets reopened, but there were a lot more applications for Stan's shops and whatever. So we stayed in Athens Square. And we continue having classes there Monday through Friday at 9am is a nice morning, the birds are chirping, and it's right under like a canopy of very lush trees. It's beautiful, the temperatures perfect at that time. And, and then we also added classes in Astoria Park, which is a little bit further north. On the pool deck, there's like another open area deck overlooking the Astoria Park pool, which I think, don't quote me, but I do believe the Astoria Park pool is the largest in ground pool in New York City, I think, I think it has that designation being the largest. It's awesome. It's an awesome pool overlooks the pool, which then overlooks the river, which then overlooks to the skyline of Manhattan, which is one of the most gorgeous sites in the world. And yeah, it's very, very cool. And so yeah, so and we've continued, yeah, yeah, we've continued we, during the winter months, once. Since we have indoor space available now, we didn't do winter classes outdoors. But we are still doing spring, summer and autumn classes outdoors. And I think we will continue for the rest of the life of our studio.


Nick 17:06

You do need that kind of perfect combination of first open space because you know, at The Astoria Park classes, we get over 40 mats thrown down, you know, and because that, that when we do on weekends, Saturday, Sunday at noon, perfect time, it's the weekend, so that one gets very popular. The Athens Park, it's a Monday through Friday class 9am during work hours, so it's not as crowded as that. But yeah, that Astoria park one is full. So we definitely need a large space in case a lot of people come out. Ideally flat, the flatness isn't a deal breaker, it could be somewhat hilly, it could be but best case scenario is flat. And then also an area where you know, you people wouldn't otherwise want to like sit down and picnic and camp, you know, like, basically, at Athens Park and the Astoria Park pool deck, we're not going to have one of those situations where we walk on up and there's just like a bunch of people with their blankets out having a picnic and we're like, oh, shoot, it took our yoga space. What do we do? Oh, do you guys mind moving like we don't want to do that to anyone. So the courtyard in Athens Park is not like a sit down and picnic place. It's a you know, place people just walk through. And so we can easily just sit down or yoga mats and do our thing. The Astoria Park pool deck, people walked by, but nobody's just going to sit down and spend the afternoon on the pool deck there, you know.


Nick 18:46

So you have to find that, yeah, that place, it's large, it's flat. And it's not going to be a place where you know, people are going to want to have a picnic otherwise. So there are a lot of community gardens in the East Village. I walked by them a lot when I'm like handing out flyers and whatever. But some community gardens have open space, but it's very like rocky and hilly. Some community gardens are nice and flat, but they're very popular picnic destinations. And so it would be hard to clear it out for a yoga class. Or maybe they're small and flat. Or maybe they're like flat and people aren't having picnics, but they're very small. And there isn't much room you can maybe get like five minutes at most type of thing. So haven't found, like the right perfect spot. You know, Washington Square Park is pretty popular. There's a lot of people there. It's hard to clear out space for a yoga class. Tompkins Square, also very popular. So I'm definitely looking, if you have any ideas you know, let me know I mean, you're busy enough with school and everything but um, yeah, yeah, definitely. We we're on, we're on the lookout for a good outdoor spot for sure. And these village area. Yeah, it's true.


Nick 20:07

Yeah, we've, we decided not to do the hybrid thing. You know, maybe to some extent, you always kind of wander off, you have to deal with like tech issues during class, which may happen just when you start trying to play music that happens, wait, why isn't my Spotify working? What's going on, we're trying to get the music going again. So there's always bound to be maybe some tech issues. We did not do the hybrid. I, I, okay, I can recognize how helpful tech can be for yoga instructors who want to keep in touch with their communities, you have your student who has to move halfway around the world for a job, and they just really love connecting with that particular instructor. And now we have this available this, the availability to have an instructor and a Student Connect halfway around the globe, through yoga, and that's wonderful. And actually, I know a lot of people who talk about getting their start in their yoga journey through YouTube videos, you know, and awesome, hell yeah, whatever, whatever gets you on the mat, it's wonderful. So that's very true. And that's why I do think that the, the use of technology with the yoga is very individual case by case, you know, evaluation. It is, I guess, you know, at the risk of, you know, sounding like an old Grump. And, at the risk of sounding that way, and hope it doesn't come across that way, is, you know, I think it's worth also remembering that the in person experience is hugely valuable. And it there's an energetic exchange that cannot be harnessed when there's a technological filter. So, you know, coming to a yoga class in person has, has a very beautiful vibration to it. And, you know, it, there's a place for that, and I guess, I've chosen to dedicate my energy and my pursuit of yoga as a practice, and I guess, as a career, if you want to call it that, solely to the in person experience. And, and then, and then I think, I think that's good for those who do have, you know, access to the technological experience. So those who want to use the technology and the remote classes to connect with their community. Beautiful, they have that and I, my energy doesn't interfere with theirs and, and they do their thing. And, and I think it then creates the mosaic of, of spreading the ancient teachings more widely. And, and so I think, yeah, the bringing the technology into the yoga practice, it's, it's finding its groove, it's harmonizing those, there are those who are figuring out how to use it very mindfully and responsibly and to benefit their community. And then there's those who are, you know, keeping it in more old school, you know, through the in person classes and I'm, I find myself falling more into that latter camp.


Nick 24:10

Yeah. I love talking about the other instructors and lineages that inspire me. So yeah, thanks for getting a chance to indulge in that. But yeah, I found I resonated very well with Jivamukti Yoga, you know, the teaching I just, you know, I really enjoyed the classical teachings and the Jivamukti method inspired me to enjoy chanting I never really the few times. I tried chanting in Sanskrit and trying to form my mouth around these harmonies. i It was hard or whatever, I didn't connect with it. Jivamukti was the first time that I started to like feel a kind of groove, a flow with chanting In and I really liked that. And also Jivamukti, they had like a really nice setup with a vegan cafe that's like right there part of the studio. They had a class every hour on the hour. It's just it's like nice, perfectly manicured community setup. And there were two teachers there. One was Rima Rabbath, who had this like, unbelievable ability. First to just one I mean, like, you know, mechanically speaking, she just has a wonderful memory and remembers everyone's name. Okay, wonderful, you know, it's a nice thing. And she's not the only one who remembers people's names. But that's no small feat. Like, that's hard. She always does. But more than that, she, she, she addressed people not just remembering their name, but there was like a, like a real honest, you know, like, there's very, like genuine interest in who she's talking to, and who that person's cousin is and the friend that they brought, and that thing they did last weekend, and she seemed to like, genuinely not in a way that she's like, Oh, I Okay, see this person? Okay, let me put on my good Rima face and remember the name of Baba, but like, there was just something very real and human. She just seemed to really care about how people are doing. And, and I just always felt good in her class like she had she had classes that were huge, but you just always felt seen you always felt like oh, Rima sees me. Wow, I'm the most popular one among the 60 people, and I'm sure everyone felt that way, you know, just really awesome. And so it felt like real community when I would take Rima's class. And then there was a another teacher there, Jules, who just he was like this, like genius. In the ancient teachings. He he knew the texts, and he knew the verses. And he knew the stories and the the parables in the myths, and he knew the science and he knew the anatomy and he knew how to play a harmonium really well. And he just seemed like the kind of guy who just genuinely, like, yoga wasn't like a trendy thing that made him like look cool at a party. It was like, like a very serious life calling for him. That's how I felt. And I mean, it's I don't think it's just how I felt and He's genuinely the way it is. It's a life calling for Jules. And he shares that. And I think that when he teaches it's, it's he teaches through inspiration, you know, he just shares his love and he's got like the Michael Jordan effect. It's, it's not just that he puts up a bunch of points that he loves putting up the points more than any other player on the court. And that's what makes them great. And I think Jules has that, he just genuinely seems to love the, the teachings and so he just shares his love of the teachings and so, so I, I dedicated my practice to the Jivamukti lineage and when I found out that Jules and Rima were leading a teacher training together in Costa Rica, it's like, sign me up. This is a no brainer. I was like, I'm going. And so I signed up for the teacher training with Jules and Rima and then I, you know, became certified Jivamukti instructor. And, yeah, I'm very happy. I still take Rima's class. She has a studio on 27th Street, which is really beautiful. And I take her class, and Jules lives in Germany, but he travels and when he's in town, I'll take his class.


Nick 28:44

Katonah, I find very fascinating. I mean, it's interesting, you know, the art types and the 90 degree angles. I get a lot of joy going into Katonah classes, and many of my friends who I respect so much for their intellect and their discipline are deep into Katonah study. And I've seen how it really does a world of good for those who get into it. And yeah, St. Mark's Yeah, there are several you know, Brian and Cassie and Greg, you know, they're deep into the Katonah study. And and that's and there are also all seasoned instructors from Jivamukti. Like Matt Lombardo, Luis Dvila, they're, they're on the St. Mark schedule. nd it's kind of cool at St. Marks. So we have this sort of like several lineages coming together in this, you know, dense urban, cultural melting pot that we call East Village, New York City. And we all kind of and yeah, it's so, it's so historic and it's so cool and the energy. I mean just think about like the names that have walked by there and you know, the people punk rock and Kerouacs. And, you know, you think about what, what what kind of like a creative lineage exists in that area and there's something about it, you just walk through those streets and there's a vibration, it's unique to any place on planet Earth really, when you consider who's walked there before you and what they've left to the history of humanity. Walking in that area, you're like, whoa. Like, like, you can feel it, you just feel like this is like you're in, you're in a vibration of creativity unique on Earth. And it's very cool. And I like to think that.


Transcribed by https://otter.ai

elementText.text:
Summary

  • Introduction to yoga. 0:00
    • Nick is the owner and operator of Yoga Agora in Astoria, Queens and St Mark's yoga in the East Village.
    • Yoga is the perfect recipe for physical, mental and social health benefits.
  • Opening a yoga studio in Astoria. 2:42
    • Astoria was a great neighborhood in 2010, especially for artists and creatives, and especially for those in the theater community.
    • Yoga was hugely popular throughout the 2000s in New York.
    • Some yoga communities used trendiness to make it more financially successful, but it was expensive. Astoria was the perfect place to open a yoga studio.
    • It took about two years to open.
  • The story of Astoria. 6:56
    • The story is special in that there are a lot of old time local residents. There are a good handful of students there.
    • The community is grounded and rooted.
  • It takes a village. 9:37
    • It takes a village. During the shutdown months, they did Zoom call classes during the winter. By spring time, people were going outside.
    • Outdoor activity was proving to be safe and needed.
    • In the summer of 2020, Open Streets was still an obscure concept. Now it is popular and has evolved into a full schedule of outdoor classes.
    • 31st Avenue ws where Yoga Agora held classes during Open Streets in summer 2020.
  • The transition from open streets to outdoor classes. 13:39
    • Yoga classes moved from 31st avenue open street to another park nearby called Athens Square, which has a flat surface courtyard and a big holiday tree.
    • Open Streets reopened in spring of 2021.
    • Classes are held Monday through Friday at 9am, under a canopy of lush trees in Athens Square and classes are also held in Astoria Park.
  • Finding a good outdoor yoga space. 19:46
    • Community gardens in the East Village are popular picnic destinations.
    • Tompkins Square is also very popular. They are on the lookout for a good outdoor spot for a yoga class.
    • They decided not to do the hybrid.
    • The use of technology with yoga is individual case-by-case evaluation. The in-person experience is hugely valuable and cannot be harnessed when there is a technological filter.
    • Technology is finding its groove in yoga.
  • The Jivamukti Method. 24:10
    • Jivamukti was the first time that he started to feel a kind of flow with chanting in sanskrit. Jivamukti had a nice setup with a vegan cafe and a class every hour on the hour.
    • Rima has a wonderful memory and can remember everyone's name.
  • Yoga is a life calling. 26:52
    • Yoga is a serious life calling, and he shares his love of the teachings through inspiration.
    • There are several seasoned instructors from Jivamukti who are on the St. Marks schedule, and it's kind of cool.
    • East Village, new york city is a melting pot of several lineages coming together in this dense urban cultural melting pot.
    • Relationships are everything, and the world doesn't run on money.

elementText.text:
Interview & Contribution Form - NYC Yoga Studios Archive Website:nycyogastudiosarchive.art The primary focus of this digital humanities project is to collect, protect and share the story of how the NYC Yoga industry functioned pre-pandemic and the yoga communitys overall response to the COVID-19 pandemic restrictions (Timeline Dec 2019-Dec 2022). The NYC Yoga Studios Archive Omeka Classic digital art exhibition website showcases each studio on an interactive, geographical map with indication of the open, online, livestream option or closed status, along with any publicly available data and/or crowd sourced contributed content in the format of textual documentation, images, audio or written interviews, teacher training memories and rePections.The NYC Yoga Studios Archive site will be available to the public for a limited time and eventually permanently stored in the digital library at the CUNY Graduate Center as part of a Masters Degree Capstone project in the Digital Humanities. How this form works: 1. Use the simpliVed content submission formhereif you just want to upload a photo or media Vle and go! 2. You may use this form just to complete a written interview and skip photo/media upload. 3. Your responses to this interview will be uploaded asa a PDF and pinned to the studio name or address that you supply on the archive website. 4. You may choose to send an audio version of your responses instead, and upload it to this form. It is suggested to Vll this out using a computer :)If you are in need of any technical support, have questions or feedback for this project, please contact nycyogastudiosarchive@gmail.com.
Enter your name. This is how your name will appear on the archive with your submission.
Kate Durand
What is the name/address of the studio of your affiliation? YO BK - 20 Broadway, Brooklyn NY 11249 / 607 Manhattan Ave, Brooklyn NY 11222 / 2319B N Miami Ave, Miami FL 33127
What type or class varieties of yoga did you teach/taught for this studio and/or in general? Please list and be specific. NOTE where copyright may apply. Our three locations offer Traditional Hot Yoga (Bikram), Power Vinyasa Yoga, Yin/Restorative Yoga and Inferno Hot Pilates (HIIT). Our Greenpoint location also features Aerial Yoga.
What would you like to share about yourself as a yoga teacher orstudio owner of NY and havingsurvived this time (Dec 2019-2022) inthe industry? How did this any of the closure/layoff impact your career/outlook/life in NYC as a whole? Lockdown and the pandemic were truly a time of putting one foot in front of the other. I recognized that the isolation of lockdown meant many of our students would miss moving their bodies in community. The first day we shut down in March of 2020, we offered online classes which continued for over 1 year. In June of 2020, I began contacting hotels, restaurants and venues so that when outdoor dining reopened in July, we were able to offer 30 outdoor classes per week. By keeping our community active and engaged, we were able to successfully reopen both NY locations and expand to Miami in February 2022.
Location: If you are at freedom to share any facts or about the building and space that your studio is/was located in, please feel free to share as much as your willing. Details that concern the accessibility of the building are of highest interest. All locations are outfitted with infrared heat, showers, gender neutral changing areas and HVAC updated with bi-polar ionization to keep the air we breathe clean.
Donate Media Content to the Archive
The main concept of the archive is to build an accurate archive for history's sake and a museum of yoga studio images or memories
Upload anydigital items to the archive that might help illustrate your unique story. Size limited to 1gb, try tokeep it smaller less than 250mb. If you skip this question, your interview responses will still be uploaded to the archive. Please Title,Describe, Date, at minimum. You must own the rights to the photo. D07F2EDF-78B5-
Title,Describe, Date, at minimum. You must own the rights to the digital item.
By Chrissy Connors, March 2022. All rights reserved.
Are you or your studio participating in any interesting social justice or charitable work that you are permitted to share and want to make mention to between 2019-2023? Yes! We offer weekly community classes benefitting various causes, including Iranian Human Rights and Sexual Assault Awareness. This month we are raising funds for LGBTQ+ youth in NYC and Black Women in Wellness. All benefit classes are donation-based, open to all and available to join for as little as $5. We are very proud to stand behind these causes and opportunities for students to practice at a lower rate than our normal drop-in.
The Before, During and after of "Unprecedented Times"
A gentle reminder that no one was alone teaching yoga on zoom, or alone with their mask on in the yoga room, we did it together. We want to hear YOUR story!
In your experience, what was the NYC yoga studio culture/classroom like at your studio or in general before the coronavirus pandemic in or around 2019? Examples of the difference in the types of events that used to take place in person versus online, or how technologywas or was not a part of your classroom.You mayshare as far back in time as you wish to. Our studios have always been places for community. Pre-pandemic, majority of our students were members practicing with us 3-6 times per week and this remains true today. Our biggest shifts have been the moderation of mat spots per class (we're still operating at 75% of our original capacity to make students more comfortable) and the continuation of outdoor classes at the Box House Hotel.
What was your experience of the NYC yoga studio culture/virtual classroom like throughout coronavirus lockdown for studios in NYC (March 2020 - June 2021)? I shared a bit of this before, but lockdown was a challenging time to own any type of small business in NYC. We pay high commercial rents here which rely on cash flow. My landlords were incredibly flexible because they believed in our mission and wanted us to stay. We strived to provide different ways for students to practice within their comfort zones: in-studio, outdoors, online and on-demand.
In your experience, what was the NYC yoga studio culture/classroom like aftercoronavirus? Please include how it felt to return to in-person yoga work, especially if you had to teach in a mask. It took a while for many of our students and staff to feel comfortable in-studio again, and the spaces really feel back to normal. One big shift is the classes students seek out now: we've seen a big shift towards meditation and slower classes like yin and restorative.
Community and Connection
Great things to share are how long you've been teaching overall,details about your tenure, what that means to you and COVID-19's impact on your business/teaching career.
What was the response in your yoga community to your studios overall endurance throughout the pandemic? For example, stories about community & how it felt to try to maintain that connectionthroughout thepandemic through the screen. How did your pre-covid following stay/change/evolve with your studiothroughout covidpresent? Have any former students reconnected with you virtually from a differentplace that left the area a long time ago, if yes how did that feel? (do not share any names of students without their consent) Outdoor classes from July 2020 onwards brought in a lot of new students and we are still seeing prepandemic students return through our doors. Greenpoint and Williamsburg are transient areas but we were also incredibly fortunate in the past 3 years that people have continued to move into the area who love practicing yoga and pilates.
Props & Media: Do you know if your studio used to or stillpresently carry/sell yoga props and media? The purpose of this question is to understand the types of books that are inside of studios, and if props were still being used or removed during the Pandemic. If they were removed, were they ever replaced? Yes, we carry yoga mats, blocks, straps and a selection of yoga clothes.
Did you teach outdoors or did you studio host outdoor classes during the summers of 2020-2022? If yes, please share the location (NYC Park name, address/studio name of the rooftop, garden, backyard, common space, public pool area, beach, playground, school yard, etc) and affiliated studio and your first hand experience. Yes: McCarren Park, Domino Park, Shaffer's Landing, Dobbin Street Collective, the William Vale, the Williamsburg Hotel, the Box House Hotel and Boggart House.
Were there any unique events that you/your studio performed online during 2020-2021 that are worth mentioning? Examples: Live stream music and yoga events and dynamic workshops are of great interest. We offered 3+ daily classes from March 2020-October 2020 and paired down after that with the shift to outdoors and on-demand.
How did your pre-covid & post-covid teaching schedule change? Example: How did your schedule fluctuate as a whole - Time of day, duration of class wise, class type, location wise, hybrid based class wise? Pre-covid, we offered 60 weekly classes in NYC locations. During lockdown, this changed to 3-4 daily online and outdoor classes. Now we are above 100 classes per week.
The Now and Forever of Yoga is Digital
As smartphone apps and digital coaches take over, what do you want to share with students?
Are you or is your studio still teaching live stream classes online as of present (Jan 2023)? If yes, when did you start? List the exact date or year if you know.If yes, where were your remote classes located? No and we don't miss them!
Teaching & Technology: The goal is to learn the impact of tech on yoga teaching.Feel free to answer any of these questions as it may apply. Did you teach in any hybrid capacity and what was your experience? What was it like teaching yoga in different or new ways? (livestream, hybrid, text, photos, voice memos, emails, recording yourself, etc)? What was challenging or better about it? What wereyour existing technology tools like (at-home or in-studio) at the start of the COVID-19 pandemic and what has your studio evolvedinto?Details like any technology or apps you have invested in are welcome. In our experience the hybrid model doesn't work -- it's nearly impossible for a teacher to focus on a screen and on the bodies in front of them. Livestream was a nice option when it was the only option, however I feel that students get so much more out of their practice when they are surrounded by other students and are in a space dedicated to movement.
What was it like teaching with or without music online?
We utilized music via Spotify, and fortunately Zoom's technology has evolved to stream seamlessly.
Do you still/have you chanted or use a harmonium in online classes?
Yes I play the harmonium Yes I chant Yes I do both I don't to any of these
Were any other languages outside ofEnglish used to teach yoga classes online or in person at your studio? Including ASL. If yes, which language(s). English only. We do have in-person Spanish classes now in NY and Miami.
What platform are you or your studio streaming through? Zoom Instagram Live Patreon Vimeo Uscreen Wix Facebook Other:
If you or your studio allow classes to be replayed (On-Demand), which platform is it hosted on? Zoom Instagram Patreon Vimeo Uscreen Wix Facebook Youtube Other:
Which platform do you use for digital music in class? Spotify Apple Music other

elementText.text:
Arjuna M. - Yoga Teacher, Sivananda Yoga Center. Chelsea, New York, NY.

Interview Transcript

Date of Interview: June 17th, 2023


Arjuna 0:00

My name is Arjuna, I'm a Sivananda yoga teacher. I primarily teach in New York City Center and 24th and 8th. I used to teach [at the] an ashram Upstate, Woodbourne, I was on staff in Ashram for few years like we can staff and other stuff. I did Karma Yoga there. I do karma yoga, Sivananda Bahamas, I'm a Sivananda certified TTC graduate from Sivananda Bahamas. I also did my ATTC advanced, teachers' training.


Arjuna 0:29

And the brief background. I'm from India, I grew up in yoga, that was a yogi and the Gita grandfather, ayurveda, I grew up in Sanskrit. So I'm pretty intimately familiar with Sanskrit, Hindi, yoga in general, as it grew up with that. My journey like you know, it's what I call like the spiritual awakening, right? It is, something that happens as a consequence or what is called karana vairgya. Karana is the reason for somebody getting on the path, which can be many forms, it's not necessarily doing something physical or some divine thing to do something outside of yours, thine own self, right? So stepping outside of that, that limited self being and for that somehow there's a lot of pain and suffering back then. And this Dharma Mittra teacher, actually there's this guy called Dharma Mirtra, I'm not sure if you're familiar with Dharma Mittra studios. And she was a Dharma Mittra and a Bikram teacher, she was a French teacher and seventy years old. And I was really suffering because even I was. And then she really took me under her wing, she was teaching me back into yoga. I know, I know, Sanskrit, you know. And then slowly I got into Sivananda and I was doing karma yoga. And and, and I didn't realize that I had all this knowledge from India and I was totally lost in America. And then it's nice when, when the student awakens, the teacher shows up, right, so that's the way it goes. So and then one blessing of another's showed up. And this was many years of practice and, and obstacles, like I had my shoulder dislocated I yhink a week before I was supposed to do my first teacher training at Sivananda. I was injured in some martial arts and all that, that the shoulder popped back up again. And I couldn't go to the teachers training, I was so disappointed. So there are obstacles. And then somehow, you know, the journey continued. And I got another opportunity to do my TTC and ATTC. So this is like I would say 2014, 2015. So 2012, 13 range.


Arjuna 2:43

Yeah, I was teaching in the center for the regular class 3:30pm on Saturdays for many years. It was like a big class, people like I, this, I particularly felt for this one woman. And a lot of regular I love to teach a 3:30pm class. So we build this together, feeding off of the energies and building up the momentum. It's a boat. Student is no above or below. When somebody is teaching. It's just a it's a it's, it's, it's, it says in the prayers. So but yeah, so yes, I was stitching all the way before the COVID hit. Yeah, so thanks for asking. Again, it's a it was pretty hard and, and, and emotional for a lot of people and a lot of suffering with families and things and looking around and the shutdown and the uncertainity and the anxiety and the fear, which is exactly what yoga is supposed to alleviate a little bit of peace of through that pranayama and the breathing and the mind control. To be fairly honest, like I did for my personal side of point of view, it did not affect me much in terms of initially did not affect me. In in a sense, I don't have case, I like in my own particular personal situation. I like you know, I also had a corporate job working there. I didn't, I was working for Bank of America actually. It's uh, it's so - I don't have financial issues. I don't have personal issues like you know, so I have pretty much relaxed from my own perspective. But then again, the whole aspect of giving off contact with the with the things has slowly started taking its toll.


Arjuna 4:32

Right like and your points I'm not a big fan of online or digital classes myself. That's that's definitely personnel. Part icular there was opportunities to teach virtual courses online. Zoom, I did. but yeah, we're gonna get deeper into the Zoom and my experiences with that. But yeah, so to start off, it was a tough period. I did not teach even a single online course. So end of story there. So that's been my experience, there were opportunities, in the there were other people teaching in the organization. Yes, it was always affiliated with the Sivananda center. But just to couple of other things, there were other courses online that I was more interested in like Gita right to the study of the Gita, the Upanishads, and codev.


Arjuna 5:26

I got really benefited during the COVID time to withdraw within. And regarding the practice myself, I, I do a lot of my own practices, but then it's taken its toll. During the COVID, as it got deeper, I got really lost without the people who contact and the touch and even the self motivation did not work to be honest too. Because as a teacher, I do my own practices of for many years and and I did resign from Bank of America, to be honest, just on a personal note, and my friend, she was shocked. Like, I mean, who would let go was a VP of, of a investment bank. And I did that I, I resigned from the job because like any of us, that's on the personal side.


Arjuna 6:18

But then I went to Bucks County, Pennsylvania, South Jersey, where there were some studios that opened up a little bit earlier before New York opened up. And I just did not return to my condo for six months, I had to do what I had to do to try to find the context myself, try to. But yeah, I mean, in trying to teach in a backyard of a friend with a couple of other guys, things of that nature. But ya know, online, but the experiences have been tremendous. I had to do what I do to be following up some kind of people content helping or whatever that that's, that's the most important thing that got lost with the human contact and the human touch.


Arjuna 7:04

Yeah, so it was a challenge in terms of for weeks and weeks, I had one one person show up, I had two person show up. And towards the end up, this is after he initially started going and we were thinking of like, you know, Neethi runs the center, we were giving some open, open classes open, which means you do have an introduction to people who would want to come in for a, let's say, an hour of meditation that we teach course, plus a free yoga class and then having some brunch or breakfast, vegetarian lifestyle meals, which is been if you look at the contrast before the COVID and after this was pretty regular business as usual, we have open like, you know, that's the whole point, the organization Sivananda, is to disburse the teachings of Master Sivananda. And as part of that, the mission or the goal is to invite or do an open, open house with with introduction to yoga and people who were just, you know, trying to help them understand as a traditional organization and methodology, it's just not jumping in with some with with just the body movements, it is a lot more deeper for for us in terms of when you say the breath, the intimate connection between the breath in the mind control and there is also just to mention this during the COVID There are three kinds of destroying some Sanskrit it's called three kinds of suffering that people encounter one is a Japanese car, a Japanese car means it's coming from within myself, whether this life or the past life, it is a pain from past some scars and vasanas that are coming from from me and are the Baltica is is a is a pain and suffering inflicted from somebody else which might be an animal which is another human being anything and are the Dibakar which is a third which which I would find particularly interesting is caused by natural events like the tsunami in Southeast Asia and Pandemic apparently falls in that are the direct or the third aspect of that so called so I recognize it right away as a in terms of things that are in your control and things that are not and absolutely it's a it's a period of global suffering and being crazy like you know, at least like you know.


Arjuna 7:21

We do World World Peace chanting and this is a time once again to contrast before industry one on the divine life society in India Rishikesh where master was there the they have a continuous chanting ever since 1947, I believe for world peace going on. And it is a tremendous amount of, like, the thought. So we did pray a lot in that and try to participate from different, like, you know, step in and so yeah, so back to realizing that, you know, this is a so and then the mind which goes in and out of the Gunas, which is the sattva, rajas, and tamas, which is the state of the mind. And I'm not the mind I'm not the body, which is a very fundamental thing Master does attach and detach, which is you attach to who I truly am and all kinds of suffering comes from attachment to the the soul the spirit or what do you call the Atman. And then you detach from the unreal, which is the why right, which is the baker is the discrimination between the nature and, and, and the consciousness. So you detach from the mind and from the mind degenerating all this, this whole, like, you know, all the suffering comes from but anyways, so master was very clear back then. So it is the whole, but But even she went on the Bahamas got shut down, which is a major source of goodness in this world, I believe at least, and the purity and the austerities those guys do there, they really shut down. And that was a I mean, I took it personally and but then back to your point, they built up this online stuff, they were doing online courses, whatever they can, whatever you can pray for the world, whatever you can help out. There were some friends of mine who were nurses. And the frontline people who really had to take the brunt of the COVID is one thing for a guy like me can even with saying that, you know not able to have this human contact. And guess what there are frontline people who are healthcare practitioners who were nurses with emergency and all this. And, and the courage they had to go through it was I did my best to please the people I know trying to, you know, get some pranayama going or trying to give them the moral support or just to talk to somebody either through voice or digital media. But yeah, it was tough time trying times and hope I answered. Much. Yeah, so it's nice to remind us, it's absolutely back to normal as far as I am concerned, personally, but not completely normal. Apperently for example, you're asking about the satsang. Last week, I think there's only Satsang on Wednesdays, but there's no Satsang on Sundays, there are certain things like that which are not fully and there is apparently lack of staff because it takes a lot to maintain the New York Center with like the International Yoga Day, the United Nations whatever that is actually India, I believe India's mission, like the official representation of India in the United Nations, they push for the International Day and they apparently reached the New York City Center and it was turned down because we don't have staff you know, it is sad to see that. So there is some repercussions that is going on. But having said that, just to take a step back Mastiff that was something interesting. And there were issues were in in the classroom there was this this she's she's still here she comes in every week. She's a hypersensitive Japanese lady. She's very very hypersensitive to to the air. Even though she wears a mask the teacher wears a mask I was wearing a mask, it was always she raises the windows up during the Cold which is during the November and and during the season where it affected other students. So it was like a normal kind of a challenge. How do you how do you slowly trying to convince and we finally came to some agreement nowadays at least after the masks are gone to that she could do it before the class starts. So it's how I'm giving her the freedom to experience the spaciousness and and and during the cold and so on. But then again I just slowly explained to her like you know it's you're affecting somebody else who's she's look at her she's almost he doesn't have a sweater or a jacket or jacket. He's downstairs so there was challenges in that nature.


Arjuna 14:37

And donning the mask itself is a big thing because the whole point is the the primer coming in through the nostrils and a couple of bodies and in some some Pranayamas we don't even teach and it's highly rusticus and such which needs a little bit more. But at least even those two If there was some kind of pranayama obviously, initially when things start settled in, and of course following New York City mandate of when the mass, but the moment it came back the first thing that comes back in is a pranayama because that's how we distinguish ourselves in Sivananda as compared to every other things. And Swami Vishnu who started the organization in the west and.., he and the pranayama goes at the end of the class normally, and he pushed it to the start of the class just to because that's the most important thing is the mind that drives the body. Because the body is the hardware, it's in the mind is the one so to have the proper especially to in terms of COVID pranayama is in in unbelievable, it's just stabilizes the mind the central nervous system, it has so many benefits, somebody needs to read the whole art of pranayama the prana, apana udhana, there's so many different kinds of how and and...


Arjuna 16:02

So yeah, so the first thing that came back in was a friend of mine in my personal class occasion, I don't know about other Sivananda teachers in my class. If you if you just do the pranayama and if you just lay in savasana the rest of the postures you are equally in my view as you did your class with a warrior just like somebody standing on one finger, or a headstand and stuff. So the point is the importance of pranayama which is, which is, drives the mind so yeah so the once the masterered it I was so happy, get the regular staff.. and people start showing up by still like four or five people. element.name: Time Summary
