elementText.text:
Arjuna Sivananda Yoga Teacher, Chelsea NYC

Summary

  • Introduction to Arjuna. 0:00

    • Arjuna is a yoga teacher who primarily teaches in new york city center and polycotton eight. She grew up in yoga and is intimately familiar with sanskrit yoga.

    • He was injured in some martial arts a week before he was supposed to do his first teacher training.

  • The beginning of the end of her journey. 2:27

    • Yoga is supposed to alleviate a little bit of peace through pranayama, breathing, breathing and mind control.

    • The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on yoga and ttc and ATTC

  • Teaching online courses. 4:42

    • There were opportunities to teach virtual courses online during the covid-19 pandemic, but james did not teach a single online course.

    • The most important thing that got lost during the pandemic was the human touch and the touch and even the self-motivation.

  • The challenges of opening a meditation center. 7:06

    • The challenge of only having one or two people show up for most of the time during the covid-19 pandemic.

    • The difference in business during and after the pandemic

    • The mission and goal is to invite people to an open open house with an introduction to yoga and a traditional organization and methodology.

    • Three kinds of suffering during the pandemic.

  • The state of the mind and body. 10:04

    • Sattva rajas and tamas are the state of the mind and the body. Master does attach and detach. All kinds of suffering comes from attachment to the soul.

    • The courage and courage they had to go through it was to try to please the people they know, trying to get some pranayama going or to talk to somebody through voice or digital media.

    • The satsang is back to normal, but not completely normal.

  • Challenges of wearing the mask. 14:33

    • The first thing that came back in was a friend of mine in his personal class, a friend who is a warrior.

    • The importance of pranayama is the mind that drives the body, because the body is the hardware, and the mind is the one.

  • Dealing with cancellations and cancellations. 17:00

    • Nithi was shocked when four people showed up after a class was cancelled, and she took it personally. She kept showing up after that every week.

    • The nature of nature is dualities in nature. The pleasure, pain, happiness and happiness just swings and unfortunately, there is no control.

  • When classes started coming back to normal. 19:50

    • When things started falling back into normal, classes started coming up and the boom influx of 15 or bigger classes, which was a normal before the covid-19 pandemic.

    • His mission and goal is simple, even if one person felt like they had some piece, he doesn't care about the rest.

  • No end to the suffering cycle. 21:57

    • There is no end to the suffering cycle. The human mind and the beast are constantly going out, especially in new york city.

    • Yahara is just filling the mind within.

  • Tapping into the spiritual energy within us. 24:03

    • New york city is the perfect place for yoga. It comes with a lot of experience and pain, so the motivation is coming from the lineage connection.

    • Sivananda is one of the very authentic, authentic, I know the lineage, so it is a very authentic

    • Yoga in New York is all about the mind, the mind and emotions, and how the mind gets captured by the objects and stays there for years and then we wake up.

    • Two things to learn from authentic sources, get to the spirituality of the person and stay centered.

Summary

  • Serge's background. 0:00
    • Serge is known as serge cashman in Israel and Serhiy Izyumovin Ukraine, which nobody can pronounce in English.
    • Serge started teaching at a local studio four years ago.
  • Taking over a yoga studio. 1:27
    • How Sunset Park was gentrifying quickly, and how he was scared that he would go broke in three months.
    • Why he decided to take over the studio.
    • They were struggling in the beginning because they had to change a bunch of teachers and the clientele.
    • Every new business needs a year or two to build a brand identity.
  • The start of the Zoom classes. 6:14
    • The pandemic forced them to shut the whole thing down indefinitely, so they had to adapt for the zoom classes.
    • They eventually settled on zoom for the classes.
    • One of the teachers proposed to run donation classes in Sunset Park in the beginning of the first summer of the pandemic.
    • The classes became quite popular and became a thing.
  • Moving out of the studio. 10:46
    • It takes time for people to be comfortable to get back into the studio. They were told by their landlord that they had to close it.
    • They were given two months' notice to move.
  • Yoga for the Latino community. 12:42
    • Yoga is too far out for most of the community and community that they were catering to, and the locals are not interested in yoga.
    • Yoga for rich people.
    • The student that offered them the space to teach gave it to them for free for like half a year.
    • They are going to restart the park classes this weekend.
  • The decline of charismatic yoga teachers. 17:12
    • A lot of charismatic teachers have stopped teaching even before the pandemic or have scaled down or shut down.
    • YogaWorks closed all of their studios in New York city after the pandemic.
    • Yoga works split up because the rent was too high.
  • How he became a yoga teacher. 21:37
    • About 10 years ago, he was a student for a long time and a teacher for a couple of years after taking his 500 hours teacher training.
    • The selection process for yoga teachers. His mentor.
  • Recuperate your recuperate. 23:49
    • The concept of a student begging the teacher to take him as a student, and how the west came to know about Krishnamacharya..
    • How the west got to know Krishnamacharya.
    • The maharaja of mysore,

    • The story of a Russian woman who became a professional skier, and how the pandemic changed the way Zoom became a dominant force.
    • Zoom is not the best solution, but it did work.
  • Why Zoom works? 32:19
    • One of the reasons Zoom works is because you can sign into a one account with multiple devices.
    • Zoom is functional and interactive, but not as much as laz right now.
    • Yoga refers to several completely different things, so it is important to find the teacher and the community who can relate to you.
    • Yoga is an ominous.

elementText.text:
Shelly Yang Form + Flow Studio Owner Interview Transcript

[00:00:00] My name is Shelly Yang. I started Form and Flow in [the] summer of 2019 and we are a wellness yoga and mindfulness studio. We're in Long Island City in Queens. A good six, seven months, It built really great momentum and then COVID hit and we closed for almost a year and then reopened in 2021. Some people they they move out of the area due [to] personal reasons. So people come and go. But yes, we had online classes. It was not very well attended. It was very difficult to build a community and following during that time. But we are so blessed with the most amazing team of teachers and facilitators and they were willing to teach every single day for a huge pay cut. They were still there, still show up for even if it's just 1 or 2 students online, they will still teach no matter what. In the studio and during COVID, we would have very few, maybe 1 or 2 students that were willing to also just come in and practice privately with the instructors. And our landlord helped, so we pulled through. We were just blessed, so very grateful. Like we're not a franchised, commercialized yoga studio. We don't have the budget to, like, set up this whole online equipment, like high tech stuff. So sometimes the quality is a bit low for a live stream. Students. So I would feel responsible. I feel bad sometimes if the quality is not as good, but in-person is definitely preferred. So it was like some people were just paying a few dollars for a class, but we're really just wanted to keep it going and.

[00:02:03] Sometimes I'm very naive. It never occurred to me that we wouldn't make it. It was like, of course we'll make it to - to reopen. So we'll just keep doing it and then it'll be okay. We love this community. It's really the best. Beautiful people and the practitioners that come to this space are mostly curious and open. They are beginners, so they're very open to receive and willing to learn. So we love this community, very friendly. It's a happy vibe and you feel it the moment you step in to our studio. It's a it's a very joyful, uplifting vibe. Chinese is my native language and there's so many Asian - there's a big Asian community here. And I always thought about just teaching myself to teach a class in Chinese. I speak fluent. It's my native language and I don't know the technical term. Thinking about, so when we have we've had a few sound meditations here where people on wheelchairs would come in through this door and they would sit in their wheelchair for our sound and Reiki sessions. And that was incredibly powerful healing to them. They were in tears after and this has happened a few times. So it's very sometimes it's even to me when I'm witnessing, when I'm watching and observing this happen, I was like, Wow, like, good job, Shelly, for creating the space and opportunity to allow that to happen. Like to allow people with disabilities to come and participate in these modern healing modalities. Right? I think. It's a very profound field. And yoga, it's not just asana, right? As we know, it's not just a physical practice. So I would really love to encourage people to dive into the deeper layers of themselves. And it might not be smooth sailing. You might realize who you truly are. You might even be a bit scared by what you will discover about yourself, your environment, your surroundings, maybe your family, your loved ones, your friends. But this path is a beautiful path to [un-un-] unveil to peel the layers of the self. And that's what the yoga, philosophy, Buddhism philosophy teaches us to look so deep into who you are and reach for that light. I think that's what we're here in this lifetime to do, rather than surfacing on the societal things, rather than working 9 to 5 or making money or providing for something. But what is there more? What is your true mission or purpose in this lifetime? What is what are you here really to do? I think yoga is a great starting point to quiet down our mind to to tune out from the external stimulus so that we can make a distinction between [distinction] between the outer world and our inner world.

elementText.text:
Interview Transcript / Summary

Thomas 0:01

My name is Tom or Thomas Sutherland. I was the second owner I acquired a small boutique studio on the Upper East Side called Medicine for the Soul Yoga on 84th between second and first. Medicine for the Soul was originally started by two sisters in 2018, in september 2018, who were just absolutely amazing. It was, it was Kristin and Amanda Vasquez who started the studio. And they had just come out of their training their 200 hour training. Amanda was also a certified Reiki teacher, I think she was level two or level three. And Kristin was more of a power yoga, and yin yoga, because that was, that was always a nice mix kind of teacher. And so they wanted to open up their own space, they started teaching gosh, probably 15-20 classes a week when they first started. And they were also going to school, and they had full time jobs. I know Kristin was a nurse, and I think Amanda was doing something in, in a more of a legal side. But they had their hands full as we as we tend to do as New Yorkers. We tend to do many things at once. But after a year, they had about five, six teachers. They were, you know, when I started to become interested, you know, when they put up the studio for sale, they had about 11, 12 classes a week, and they were just doing whatever they could to, you know, to keep going. And they really wanted to see Medicine for the Soul continue on. They didn't want to close it, you know, I think financially, they, they weren't making ends meet. You know, despite the studio's revenue itself, and then they just had so much going on, I think they really needed to finish school and they wanted to, you know, they had had some other priorities going on. And they're also new to New York, which was not easy. You know, it takes it takes time. You know, they say you don't become a New Yorker until you're there for 10 years, right? Walked your, walked your million step around the city. So yeah, I came in and, you know, we had a really, really nice agreement. You know, I acquired the studio, as we started on September 1. My partner, my girlfriend, Shavonne, was a really big helper, kind of a mentor, in a way, you know, kind of a coach because she was also living in she's, she was there for, like, 11 years, you know? This is around the time that her and I met started hanging out and started dating. And yeah, we just took on this project with, with a lot of inspiration. And it was something that I had always wanted to do.


Thomas 2:55

My first training was in hot yoga in 2012. So I think at this point, 2023 I've been practicing yoga for about 14 years been teaching, or was teaching for about 11. And, yeah, this is something I've always wanted to do. So I acquired Medicine for the Soul, and I met with the teachers, you know. We carried on with the same schedule, and, you know I've always seen people go into a business acquisition, and they just change things, you know, considerably and instantly. But I knew that, you know, you have to keep the essence of what the business is, you know, the essence of what Medicine for the Soul is and the energy and the community. And, you know, what, what it means and just kind of, you know, worked out that my vision was very much in alignment with what Kristin and Amanda were doing, and giving a lot of freedom to their teachers delivering more authentic, yet affordable classes and other some not very affordable classes in New York. It can, it can range in price, but, you know, we we were surrounded, at the time.


Thomas 4:02

I was also managing a studio, don't, don't tell them. I was managing the YogaWorks, Upper East Side studio, and I acquired Medicine for the Soul at the same time. So it was, I was, you know, during my lunch break, I would run up to 84th Street from 78th street to go clean the studio, you know, and then run back to go check in for the you know, 12:30 class kind of thing. And then afterwards at five I'd leave. You know, because those classes until 8:30-9 o'clock and then after after I leave around five or six and they're all good for the evening with the front desk staff. I'd run back up and then check people in for the 6:30 and 7:30 You know, just nuts as we do. Yeah, it was just, it was a great experience. I really, I really, really enjoyed you know, having the studio we you know, like I said we acquired in September 2019. So this was, you know, just a few months before the big the big change you which was ...


Thomas 5:00

I still remember the date it was March, March, it was a Tuesday was a March 16. Which is when, you know, we all got the call and the message that we had to shut down. But, you know, we basically went from September, I think February was our first profitable month is incredible. We went from, you know, 11, 12, 13 classes a week with five, six teachers, including myself, to 22 teachers and about 45 classes a week. So it was just a huge, it was yeah, it's just a massive turnaround. And, you know, what I was saying is we were surrounded by kind of the best yoga in New York, you know? We were surrounded by, we had YogaWorks down the street. We had Lululemon that's just not Lululemon, what do they call it? Laughing lotus, that's the one, you know, so that they opened up on 80th. I think they're on 84th and Lexington, actually, they're on fourth and Lex. And then you had Pure Yoga, which is on 86th and third. And you had a couple other, you know, Mom and Pop boutique studios down the street on first. Anyway, you had kind of the best, and they had CorePower, which was, you know, taken over there like Subway. And you know, and they're just on every corner. And, you know, we just had the best yoga in New York kind of right around us. You know, I think the only one that was missing probably would have been Yoga Vida. element.name: Time Summary
element.description: A summary of an interview given for different time stamps throughout the interview

elementText.text:
Summary

  • Introduction. 0:01
    • Tom Sutherland acquired a small boutique studio on the Upper East Side called medicine for the Soul Yoga on 84th between second and first avenues.
    • The original owners, Kristin and Amanda Vasquez.
  • Acquiring a yoga studio. 2:02
    • Acquiring Medicine for the Soul was not easy, and it takes time to become a New Yorker. It takes 10 years to become one.
    • Her first training was in hot yoga in 2012, and she has been practicing yoga for 14 years and teaching for 11.
  • The turning point of the business. 4:40
    • The studio was acquired in September 2019, a few months before the big change. They went from 11-12 classes a week with 5-6 teachers to 22 teachers and 45 classes per week.
    • They were surrounded by the best yoga in New York, including YogaWorks and Pure Yoga.
    • When the pandemic came, there was a lot of uncertainty, especially in a very hands-on, intimate type of business.
    • The final decision came when the government mandate came out just to be actually shut down. The first thing that everyone started doing was teaching online.
  • How did you incorporate technology into your business? 10:09
    • They started teaching on Zoom, and started incorporating other technology. They started streaming live classes with their phones and using other services.
    • They brought in another piece of technology called Box Cast.
  • Transitioning from a studio to online classes. 12:05
    • One of the best examples of a yoga studio being successful during the pandemic was Vimeo. They brought in high-quality equipment and made the best quality classes.
    • The transition from purchasing the studio and six months later not even going to an online platform.
    • The importance of asking the question, what are you teaching? What is the purpose of your class? What do students get out of it?
    • Giving students the freedom to create their own class, from the title of the class to the description to what they teach.
  • Learning online. 16:34
    • They were able to grow their community and develop a schedule and grow the community by teaching online.
    • In the beginning, 60% of the teachers that they had initially had initially stayed with them, and she started to transition the site over to WordPress.
  • Teaching online is different from teaching in person. 19:10
    • Teaching online is different from teaching in person. It's about personality, looks, confidence and confidence. Online is a little bit more of a workout than in-person classes.
    • Medicine started to get more and more subscriptions and set up an online subscription model, which was $14.99 a month.
  • Focus on quantity over quality in pricing. 21:30
    • Medicine for the Soul was accessible and grounded, and tried to beat the market with pricing and focus on quantity over quality.
    • Cloudera, a tech company based in silicon valley offered them a contract for their online platform, with a new website and wordpress, serving 1200 people around the world.
  • Yoga with a DJ at House of Yes. 26:05
    • One of the first classes they did was a Friday night DJ class with a DJ at House of Yes in Brooklyn.
    • They had six corporate companies that were signed on with them.
  • Zooms impact on the business. 28:43
    • The event was an all-hands meeting on a Friday afternoon to unplug by plugging into zoom. It was incredible, and it was a temporary solution to the pandemic.
    • The site Medicine for the Soul is no longer a website or URL, but there are close to 300 class videos on YouTube.
    • The Medicine for the Soul Wellness on YouTube channel has 265 subscribers and 200 videos.
    • Closing Medicine was also a closing of a chapter in his life, and it was a right of passage for him and the teachers that taught there.

elementText.text:
Keela 0:00

I'm Keela Williams. My studio is New Love City. We're in Greenpoint, 68 Greenpoint Avenue 4th floor. I'm the owner. I actually am not - There was a previous owner, I I bought the studio from her, I took over. I've been there the whole time, I was teaching the whole time, but actually took over January 1 2020. So that was a real ride. Um, but yeah, we'll be, we'll be eight at the end of July.


Keela 0:36

We decided to do like a clean break of like January 1st, to have it just be like a new year. Um, that January, we had a really good month, I was nuts. I was riding high. I was like this is, it might have been the best month we'd had! But maybe not, I'd have to look back at the numbers. But it was a very good month for us.


Keela 0:57

Things were going well, in February, I was actually at I was hosting a retreat, a yoga retreat in Palm Springs that March, 2020. And that's when things start to get a little get a little crazy. And I remember my manager of the studio calling and saying like, what do you want me to do? Like, this COVID thing is happening, and I don't know what to do. And I just said buy as muchh and sanitizer as you can and I'll be back in like three days. And I flew back after the retreat, I think we shut down March, I think it was March 16th around there. And then we were shut for 427 days. Not that I was counting. Um, it was really scary and really, like, isolating because I was also the sole owner. And now I have this business on my hands. I'm, I'm in debt, because I took out loans to purchase the business. And you know, there's zero, there's zero money coming in. So, you know, that was that was scary. And hairy. And also COVID was scary.


Keela 2:09

So it was like, the we, I'm fortunate that I have a background in like tech and design, I was a project manager for design studios for like 12 plus years. Before I before became a yoga teacher, and then a studio owner. So I had a little bit of that knowledge already of like how to project manage how to like, how to pivot quickly how to create an online platform. So we very quickly pivoted to online, we just immediately started doing Instagram lives, because that was like the lowest barrier to entry. And we would just set up a tripod and I would teach a class on Instagram Live to these, you know, students at home. We then really quickly figured out that if you very quickly after you in the Instagram Live, if you push download, you could download the whole video. This is not that way anymore, I don't think but this was the technology at that time. So if you're really quick, after you ended it, and you remember it and you downloaded it, which is the thing I taught my teachers, then we would have that hour class. So then we would take that hour class and we would have a library of these classes. So then we built I built a Patreon page. I mean, those times were, those times were wild. I was up all night out to teach and film these classes during the day. I would be up all night like editing them trying to figure out the best way to like get them up quickly. So we then launched our Patreon page, which actually was really successful. Or I should say that our community is very, very loyal and wonderful. And they were like, What do you need, and I was like, I need you to join this Patreon. So at the height of our online subscription, we have like 250 patrons, which was huge. So we kept that going, it's still going, it's still live. We kept that going the entire time. We eventually moved from just doing the Instagram, we were doing like three Instagram lives a day. I think we were doing morning, midday and evening. And our teachers would just teach wherever they were, and then immediately download it and then Dropbox it to me and then I would edit it and put it on Patreon.


Keela 4:37

So you know we have the archive of all those Instagram Lives from 2020 to go back and watch them now it's kind of wild because the tone is so different. The vibe, the mood is like it's a little dark, to be honest. Like it's a little like, ooh, because we're just kind of hanging on by thread and we're like alone teaching these classes in a room alone, and then Instagram Live, there's no there's no interaction. You know, you people, could like heart things and likes comment, but you can't see them. So, yeah, it was we created a lot of content. And I think we did get a lot of people engaged. And we have all that content still, but it was it was definitely like a weird, it was a weird time. We then, our software platform for the studio is Mindbody, they rolled out a live stream, a lot of studios were doing Zoom. Um, I don't know why we've kind of shied away from that I just wanted it to be a little bit more structured. So we did Mindbody live.


Keela 5:47

And we would live stream some classes from the studio. Those you could see people if you wanted, but usually people, sometimes we turn our camera on, and sometimes it weren't. It's really hard to teach,. and it's really hard to teach an online class when everyone's cameras off. You're just like, yelling into the void. It's really weird. But we did that for a while. And then we set out, we got we got like a proper set up of a proper camera and we set everything up in the studio that's still going. And we would would film proper classes like this. The teacher would go in, they would know what they're teaching, they would shoot themselves doing it. And that way, you didn't have to be around anyone. So you can be isolated in that room. And there is you know, no threat of COVID and then you could shoot your video, and then they would be like. Okay, here's the video, here's the description, here's the title. And then I would edit them, I just taught myself how to edit in iMovie. And then we would just get those up on Patreon. And we actually just did an audit of our Patreon, because we're kind of going through and cleaning it up a little bit. And our I think it came out to like 800 videos, which is like insanity. So we've got quite a lot of content that we shot over those two years. Yeah, that's kind of how we got through regarding the online portion, and that patrons still like we still have, you know, we're we definitely don't have as many as 250 now, but that's because we're open and people come back to the studio, which we prefer. They weren't super popular, we ran them for a little while, we wouldn't get a ton of engagement that way. But we were getting a lot of engagement on Patreon. And so it just seemed like, it seemed like yes, people wanted the interaction. But I think more than that they wanted to practice on their own time. So I know a lot of students who were doing Zooms, and those were like really successful, our live stream never really took off. And was like a little bit of a pain for us. So we eventually just kind of like nixed that and continued just having the teacher fill in themselves. So that we can edit it, put it on Patreon. And they could just take - take class whenever they wanted.


Keela 8:02

We just taught the way the teacher, I encouraged my teachers to teach however they would teach. The whole class would be its own class, the whole class is demoed. So if you are hearing impaired, you can see. But and yes, we would use Sanskrit depending on the teacher, my teachers are allowed to encourage to teach however they want and whatever style and whatever language Sanskrit, English and what have you that they want. So they were just kind of being themselves, and just teaching the classes that they would teach in a studio just online, and having to demo the whole thing, obviously. Which gets a little tiresome after you're holding all the poses. But yeah, people seem to dig it. And people even now have found us via Patreon, and have either joined the studio, or come on a retreat with me. People who I have never even met who like lived in Oregon, started somehow finding our Patreon and then would like they come to Thailand with me every year on a retreat, which is just wild. So they definitely like opened up a bigger audience for us.


Keela 9:15

Yeah, music was a whole thing because music as New Love City is a big part of our culture, it's a big part of our teaching. Most all the teachers teach with, with their own playlists that they create. It's a very big part of my class. And it's a it's, it's honestly why a lot of people come to my class. And I do spend a lot of time on my playlist and then make one every week. And we didn't want to not have that. And so if you do any sort of live stream or do any sort of video production, you can't, you can't use a popular song, a normal song with unless unless you license it and not we can't afford it licenses. So we the workaround for us was to have them play it at home. So we will to create the playlist and send out the link and say like if you want to follow along, and then we figured out that either a live stream or when you are shooting it for them to watch later the on demand. You would say like, Okay, if you're playing with the playlist, go ahead and queue it up and push play and three to one. And everyone pushes at the same time in hopes that like that gets the synchronicity of like moving through the flow and moving through the playlist. And that seemed to work, okay. And we even do that now on Patreon, you can like go click a video, the playlist is at the bottom. So that was our workaround for not having to shell out tons of money for licensing or use those non licensed songs, which we all know aren't as good. Yeah.


Keela 10:50

We have one yin class on Sunday nights. We're always vinyasa with a caveat that it's completely up to the teacher. And so, you know, my class tends to be a little bit on the faster side. And then like Conor, whose class you took this morning tends to be on the slower side. And then there's everything in between. I put no stipulation on them. I just asked them to teach whatever they want. The I do, the one stipulation I put on is that they have to teach to all levels. And so all of our classes are all levels. So each teacher will say like, you know, let's go into this pose. If you want to, like level up a little bit, you can try this. And if you want to go and work and try this. So there's always usually two to three different options in each pose, just to make sure everyone feels like it's accessible to them. And they can practice with us. Yes, I do not want us to do this there.


Keela 11:41

So I, Jen Jones is the original founder owner. And you know, I was teaching there from the beginning. She just fell in love with that space. It's a beautiful space, it's fourth floor walk up, which is a little little annoying for some people. You're warmed up by the time you get up there. But this space is stunning. It's like beautiful, all the carpet floors. And there's skylight in each room. And it's a pretty big space, so it can fit quite a bit of people in the class. It's just gorgeous. And you know, Greenpoint, it's like, the best neighborhood in Brooklyn, in my opinion. So yeah, I think we're very fortunate to be where we are. And we're right there. Franklin is kind of like the main strip. So we're just right off of Franklin, which is pretty sweet. And the community in Greenpoint is wonderful to be really sweet, you know, usually a little younger crowd, who are very active and very supportive. And there is also a lot of freelancers, which is good for midday classes. Yeah, it's just it's a sweet, it's a sweet spot, both like in the community and, and location wise. And we are very close to transmitter where like, literally on that street. Funnily enough, the way I knew that that was a really good spot for yoga is I actually got married at that spot. So I knew, I knew it was a beautiful place for people to congregate, because that's sort of where I had my I had my ceremony. So we just decided, yeah, we try yoga there. And, and that worked out and there's a beautiful giant willow tree that unfortunately, fell a few years ago. Yeah, I don't know, if you saw is that she was very, very old. The tree was older than the park. And it fell after one of those big storms, which is a big bummer. We actually donated a new tree to the to the park, a baby willow. So it has been planted in that old spot.


Keela 13:42

But the library reached out to us and we were thrilled. They're so sweet. They're so wonderful. That library took so long to open. It's actually right...it's like two blocks from my house. So when it opened, I was so excited. It's a beautiful building. They actually reached out to us, and they had a little bit of they had a little bit of budget. And we decided, you know, we would we would match them. And so our teachers, the class is free, our teachers get paid. But the class is open to the public. And we run that programming spring and fall, usually summer on their rooftop is pretty hot. And we just launched kids yoga with them as well. So there's like, like storytime yoga on Thursdays at 11 that one of our teachers teachers, their little little little bitty baby like little like two year olds very cute. So that's like a fun, that's a fun partnership that we have. And even you know they usually have like a little bit of budget and I'm like, fine, like my the ethos at New Love City as a teacher gets paid really well because this is a job that you have to be, you have to do a lot of education, for you have to pay for that education. You, So you have to continue that education. It's just expensive, as you know, to be a yoga teacher in the city. You also don't get paid very well. We're trying to change that. And I do feel proud that we teach, we pay our teachers very well. So I never asked them to teach a class for free, ever. Even if it's a donation class, they always get paid by the studio. And then we can donate the proceeds from the students to whatever charity we choose. Usually this, the teacher will pick. But yeah, that, that partnership with the library is really sweet. We have one starting with the new Greenpoint market, and not this weekend. But next, though, first week in June, where we're going to do, they're doing a wellness weekend. So we're going to do two classes a day, one kids and three adult classes that weekend with them, and that, again, will be free and open to the public. So we're excited about that as well.


Keela 15:54

One thing that we did was we had these daily meditations on our Instagram that you could just jump on, it was five minutes, all those are still on our page from, you know, years ago. Kwazi, one of our incredible meditation teachers, as well as Conor would lead a lot of those. So every day, it was just a way to like, okay, let's just jump on and connect and meditate for five minutes.


Keela 16:18

I had some students, I don't one particular student who was a doctor, and she she's a doctor and like the respiratory field. so COVID was really hard for her and she was working so much. And she was really suffering, physically, emotionally, everything. So I would send her voice classes that were like 20 minutes, 25 minutes, just really digestible. Like, hey, like, here's what we're gonna do. And I would sort of send those to her every few days that she had something to do and to practice, like, I have 20 minutes, maybe in the morning, and then I have to go to the hospital, and then there for 8-12 14-16 hours, like who knows. So yeah, I would do that for her, which, which was a sweet way to connect. And then we would have our meditations. And yeah, those are really sweet. I think I had other friends who were like, can you just send me like, a morning stretch? And I was like, absolutely. And voicemail was good for that. Some students needed stuff at home, they're like, can I just borrow was like, absolutely. So they would take blocks home. And then, you know, year and a half later, when we're practicing inside they would they brought them back. So that was nice. Yeah, yeah, there, there's a core group of our members who've been with us, wherever and, you know, a lot of them were like, I'm still working. I have nothing. I have nothing to spend my money on. Because everything is closed. Just keep my membership going. Like, are you sure? And they're like, yes, just please, like, reopen when we can reopen. Please don't close. I was like, I have no intention of closing. So you know, that was nice and sweet. And and definitely helped us keep keep the doors open but closed.


Keela 18:15

So we turned five, July 2020. And I was like we I mean, we have over five we have celebrate. And so we decided we're gonna have an outside yoga party. So we decided to do the American playground. And that's really close to studio. It's on Franklin. I think is like Franklin in between denoble and Milton. It's cute little playground, there's basketball court. There's a playground for the kids. It's not very big. There's not a lot of people ever really playing basketball on that court. So I was like, oh, we'll just we'll go there. I got us a generator so that we could take our big speakers and just have this big party that a cooler we had a generator. And I asked him to film it. And we all went out and did a meditation. A class, like a class for multiple teachers would teach we kind of just like pass back and forth. And we just did it on the basketball court. But what was funny is that day good for us and bad for us just happened to be beautiful. So everyone was out playing basketball. So we were, like oh well, so we're literally..if you see any of the videos everybody we're like, you can see us like on half of the court taking up the court like people have doing yoga poses. Laying down doing yoga poses, standing up and you know music on. And then the other court, there's just like ballers just going for it and they're all over the place. We're all over the place and we're just really sweet because we didn't, they just wanted to be outside and we wanted to be outside and we just kind of made it work. Like coexisting in this space is really active space for like people maybe getting hit by a ball but they didn't care. The how is the like, was hot day so the date opened up the fire like the water would what do you call that? The like barracks underwater? Yeah. So that's going and that's like in the video and just just like a really sweet New York day, but at the same time, like the industry, Brooklyn is a Brooklyn time and at the same time, we're all like, with kerchiefs on our noses, but pulled down a little bit, but like, Are we okay? We're in the middle of COVID bubble, we're outside, but we're not close to each other. So it's just a really weird. It's a really weird time. It was really sweet. Time to like, all come together. And I remember that fondly. Yeah, so weird party that was.


Keela 20:44

Then we did so many online trainings, we did. I think we started with a thing called homeschooled. And we basically, it was it, was open to anyone. And it was just a time to sort of get online together and study yoga, it was really sweet. And mostly, it was just a time for people like being in community with each other. I think we ran three of those. We also did detent-yin, which I think might have been what you did. And we might have done two of those. And that was specifically in focus. It was the online course on yin. And then we did, then we did a 200 hour in the fall of 2020. And we did a hybrid inside, we all signed a social contract that we were gonna be really safe There were some rules around like, you know, people that you see in density, so that on the weekends, we could be in the studio. And during the week, Monday, Wednesday, Friday, we will be on Zoom. That was one of our most successful teacher trainings we got because of the way we ran it because of the timing people who had like real jobs, so that an air quotes, like day jobs were allowed to join because of the timing. And honestly, it was such a successful teacher training, we got so many teachers out of that training because of that, like I think we hired, which we don't normally do. Normally it's like zero to one. We hired like four teachers out of that training, because they were all just fantastic. They're still with us. Spring 2021, it was most, I think COVID kind of got a little dicey in this, so I think that one was online the whole time. That was hard. That was really hard. And then I think, fall 2021 maybe it was hybrid again. But honestly, all that's so fuzzy, because it was just such a weird time that some of it's like blocked out. But yeah, we did.,,We did fall 2020, spring 2021 fall 2021. And then we've now are just back to doing it in the fall. And it's, it is still hybrid during the week on Zoom and the weekends in the studio. And we found that that works really well again and allows people who normally wouldn't be able to join, to join so that that is actually something that came, a positive thing that came out. Because we would have never done that before we would have never gone online.


Keela 23:20

Well, one thing I will say, you may or may not want to edit out, is that we don't prescribe to Yoga Alliance. Our teacher training is, this I know, we have the best teachers and they are so smart. And they have studied for so long. Conor, Conor is incredible. He's been doing this for so long. I'm teaching philosophy online. Yeah, easy. He taught anatomy online. He's got like a little, I think he just would share his screen and he has this fun little anatomy app on his computer. And he would just like point to it that way I taught poses online, I would literally just like do the pose and show them what it looked like. And then I would be like, Okay, stand up and you do it. Is it perfect? No. Is it doable? Absolutely. Um, so yeah, there's workarounds. And then, you know, it allows them, it allows them to be able to participate. Rather than it being an in person, you know, eight hours a day on a Saturday and Sunday, which is brutal. I do have some teacher you know, yoga is a funny profession because you do get inspired to travel. Whether that's to go to a training somewhere or go practice somewhere, or just like go travel because you're not sort of stuck to this traditional job. So I do have a teacher who's moving away and she's like, you know, I would still want to be involved like you're still absolutely involved. You know, if you want to host a retreat where you're going, we can do that if you want to, you know, teach them online, so if you can do that, but it has helped us. It has helped us continue to keep the teachers we have but I will say that our teachers, more than anything love to teach in our studio, and just we're so happy that we reopened and came back. And even though we do keep that online portion, like and even though we do keep our Patreon, like, we, we love to be together. We love to be with each other, we love to be with our students, it's a special space. So, you know, that's, that's where our hearts lie. I'm very, you know, grateful that we got some online stuff to help us stay afloat. But we just like to be in person. Yeah, it's the same.


Keela 25:35

The only difference is we don't have a 6:30am anymore, because now people don't go to work because of remote. So the thing that shifted is that we don't have a 6:30 because no one would come to it. And our 9:30's are fuller, because people are working remote, the 12:30's are fuller, because people are working remote. What kept me going was our oh, even thinking about it makes me like so overwhelmed. It was, it was hard. It was hard. My, my, my teachers and my students who were like everyone, just that we just missed each other so much, we wanted to be together so badly. And so when we did launch our park program July 2020, and had to go back and look because they all that is like really fuzzy memory, because it was such a hard time that. Like in time was just so squishy then, but when we did launch it. I just went back and looked and I taught these two night classes there. And they were both packed, you know, we tried to cap it because of like people, we didn't want too many people there because of COVID. But like they were both just like, full, because people just wanted to be together.


Keela 26:53

And, you know, I weirdly like made a lot of new friends during that time, because people who stuck around in New York and then they would come to park yoga, and I didn't really know them very well. And I got to know them really well. So I've blossomed some new friendships. Before, I was very like kind of standoffish with students because I was like, the dynamic of teacher and student and so you don't want to get too close. I kind of feel like COVID like wiped all that away. And now I'm just like, so close to all my teachers. I'm so close to all my students in a really sweet way that, you know, we had to go through a dark time to get there. But I'm I'm very, I'm very happy with the way things ended up. I'm so so so grateful that we are still open. I'm so grateful my teachers stuck with me, that my students stuck with me. And now we're you know, we're all better for it. But, but yeah. Yeah, I think the saving grace for us was we took we took a lot of risks. We went outside, we rolled the dice to see that would work. It worked. We launched the online platform which it worked, it worked. We asked for help wherever we could get it. Like we just kind of we just did everything that we had to do to stay afloat because we knew, I knew we were going to reopen those doors. That had no and I remember one of my teachers asked me and I get really emotional, I think about it, but he's like, did you ever think about shutting? Did you ever think that was possibility? And I said, absolutely not. There was no there was no, there was no chance of it. Like we were just going to reopen. And we did and we are even more successful now than we've ever been. So yeah.


Transcribed by https://otter.ai

element.name: Time Summary
element.description: A summary of an interview given for different time stamps throughout the interview

elementText.text:
Summary

  • Introduction. 0:00
    • Keela williams is the owner of New Love City, a yoga studio in Greenpoint, New York. She took over the studio from the previous owner on January 1, 2020.
    • In February, she was hosting a retreat in Palm Springs, and the studio shut down for 427 days.
  • Pivoting to online courses. 2:32
    • She had a little bit of knowledge of how to project manage and pivot quickly. She quickly pivoted to online and started doing Instagram lives.
    • She was up all night editing the classes during the day, trying to figure out the best way to get them up quickly.
  • How did the online portion of the business go? 5:08
    • They created a lot of content during the pandemic, but it was a weird time. They did Mindbody live, and they would live stream some classes from the studio.
    • They did an audit of their patreon, and their videos came out to over 800 videos.
  • Teaching the way the teacher wants to teach. 7:58
    • Teachers are encouraged to teach however they want, and the whole class is demoed. They are allowed to use sanskrit or whatever style they want.
    • Music is a big part of teaching.
  • About playlists. 9:34
    • They make a playlist every week. They also have a playlist for live streams and video production.
    • They give yin class on Sunday nights.
    • Jen Jones is the original founder.. She fell in love with the space and was teaching there from the beginning.
    • Greenpoint is the best neighborhood in Brooklyn, and the community in greenpoint is wonderful, with a young and supportive community.
  • Yoga with the library. 14:06
    • Yoga classes are free and open to the public, and teachers get paid, but the class is open to them. They run classes in spring and fall on their rooftop in the summer.
    • They also have a partnership with the library, and they have daily meditations.
  • How to connect with your students. 16:12
    • Every day it was a way to jump on and connect and meditate for five minutes. She would send voice classes to a student.
    • Some students needed a morning stretch.
  • Yoga Party at the American playground in 2020. 18:28
    • They decided to have an outside yoga party. They decided to do it at the American playground. It's a cute little playground with a basketball court and a playground for the kids.
    • It was a really sweet New York day, but at the same time, it was a Brooklyn time.
  • Online trainings and courses. 20:34
    • Homeschooled was a sweet time for people to come together and be in community with each other. They did three online trainings, including a 200 hour in the fall of 2020 and a hybrid in-person training in fall 2021.
    • Spring 2021 was a little dicey because of COVID.
  • Teaching yoga online. 23:16
    • They would have never gone online before. They have the best teachers in the world, and they are smart and have studied for a long time.
    • Yoga is a funny profession, because teachers get inspired to travel. They love to be together and be with each other.
    • Park yoga was full during COVID-19 because people were working remote. They wanted to be together so badly that they missed each other so badly.
    • They took a lot of risks and went outside and rolled the dice to see if it would work. It worked.
